text: was wondering why do we "spin up" servers. Is it supposed to invoke that magic imagery in movies? or is the origin somewhere else?

elements.text: was wondering why do we "spin up" servers. Is it supposed to invoke that magic imagery in movies? or is the origin somewhere else?

text: Well, when a computer with a traditional (i.e. not SSD) hard drive is booted up, it does make a "spin up" sound as the hard drive starts rotating at high speed. Maybe that's where the expression comes from. From when servers would be dedicated machines with a hard drive.

elements.text: Well, when a computer with a traditional (i.e. not SSD) hard drive is booted up, it does make a "spin up" sound as the hard drive starts rotating at high speed. Maybe that's where the expression comes from. From when servers would be dedicated machines with a hard drive.

text: And large fans that also make a spinup sound maybe?

elements.text: And large fans that also make a spinup sound maybe?

text: There's quite a lot of spinning that happens in an old-fashioned computer, and even in a modern computer, although they're somewhat quieter.

elements.text: There's quite a lot of spinning that happens in an old-fashioned computer, and even in a modern computer, although they're somewhat quieter.

text: That language also confuses me a lot when talking about climate models. There are always sentences like “We consider the three first years of simulation as spinup and discard the from the analysis”

text: this was dumb, I forgot computers are real things
